On the 10th of September I was with Rierdon - we watched the two prisoners for a few minutes - they stopped at a pawnbroker's; West left the other, and went into the shop - I followed him, and saw him with these shoes on the counter; I went to the door, and told Rierdon to go on - he went and took Lilley, who was then going away; I went and asked West where he got the shoes - he said a young man at the door gave them to him to pawn; I asked if he ever saw that young man before - he said No: I took him to the door, and said, "Is this the young man?" he said No; I said,"I saw you in conversation with him" - I took them to the office; I did not know who they belonged to, but I saw the name of E. Driver, Esq. on them, looked in the Court Guide, and found him.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You saw the shoes in the shop? A. Yes - that was the first I saw of them; he denied that Lilley was the person who gave them to him.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I was outside, and took Lilley - I found nothing on him.

West's Defence. There was nothing but "Driver" on the shoes; I told the officer the person was waiting at the corner of the street, and if he would allow me to go to the corner I should be able to clear myself - he said, "No, I have got you;" in going to the watch-house he said,"Why don't you, like a good lad, say he gave them to you?" I said, "I will not bring an innocent lad into trouble;" the person asked me where the nearest pawnbroker's was - I said I would pawn them; he said pawn them for 5s. in the name of
William Ring
, Pancras-street.
JURY to FRANCIS KEYS. Q. Did he ask you to go to Pancras-street? A. Yes, but I did not, because I had seen him with the other.

WEST -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

LILLEY -
NOT GUILTY .

2045.
WILLIAM COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 1 ham, value 10s., the goods of
Anthony Medcalf
; and that, at the General Session for thedelivery of the Gaol of Newgate, held on Thursday, the 31st of May, in the 8th year of his present Majesty's Reign, he was convicted of felony, by the name of
William Davies
.

WILLIAM WEIBLE
. I am a clothes-dealer - I know Mr. Medcalf, he lives in Gray's Inn-lane
. On the 8th of October I saw the prisoner take this ham from his door - he carried it two doors down the lane, and left it at a private door; I told Mr. Medcalf, and the prisoner was taken.

ANTHONY MEDCALF
. This is my ham here.
THOMAS DELANY. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner and brought the ham.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS COLLINS
. I am an officer of Walbrook. I got this certificate from the clerk of the arraigns (read); I was sent at the conviction of the prisoner for stealing a silver spoon, and he was sentenced to one year's imprisonment in the House of Correction; I know he is the person.
GUILTY . Aged 62.
Transported for Seven Years .

2046.
JAMES CARTWRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 1 trowel, value 2s., the goods of
Joseph Taylor
; and 1 trowel, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Taylor
; and that he was in July, in the 8th year of his present Majesty's Reign, convicted of felony .

JOSEPH TAYLOR
. I am a bricklayer , and was working at an unfinished building in Percy-street, Kingsland-road
. On the 16th of October, when I went to dinner, I left my trowel concealed in a new drain in the back yard - the prisoner had no right there; when I returned I missed it - I went to several pawnbrokers and could not find it; I then went to Mr. Thimbleby's, and the prisoner was there offering it to pawn.

JOHN WILLIAM WINTLE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - this is the trowel.

HENRY FREAK
. I live with Mr. Thimbleby. The prisoner brought this trowel, and pawned it on the 16th of October: he came again and brought this other; one the prosecutor came in and claimed it.

THOMAS TAYLOR
. I am a bricklayer , and was at work at the same place. This is my trowel, which I lost from there.

RICHARD CONSTANTINE
. I am a constable. I have a certificate of the prisoner's conviction in this Court in July, by the name of
James Bates
; I took the prisoner, and know he is the person - he was ordered to be whipped and discharged.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Life .

2047.
SARAH ELIZA TATTON
was indicted for
bigamy .

ANN TATTON. I have a son named
William Tatton
- he was married to the prisoner about seven years ago, on the 28th of August, at St. Mary, Lambeth; she was married, as a widow, in the name of
Sarah Eliza Webb
- I do not know what she was, but I believe she took in needle-work; my son was a porter - he had been acquainted with her four or five months; she had one child five years old when she married - they had no children; I do not know whether they separated by mutual consent, but he allowed her 5s. a week after they had lived together two years; I have a copy of the register, which I got from the church myself on the 3rd of July, 1828; the reason I have kept it so long is, that she was in prison, and denied knowing such a person as
William Tatton
; I was present at the marriage (certificate read).

Cross-examined by J. ALLEY. Q. Who did you get the certificate from? A. From the minister himself - his name is on it; my son went to sea three years ago - he was gone fourteen months, and returned in the Ganges; the prisoner did not tell me after he was gone, hat she found a letter of his, saying he had left her for ever - I do not know whether he allowed her any support while he has been away the last three years, but the first voyage he did - he is here now.

BONDFIELD BRYANT
. I am a carpenter . I married the prisoner at St. Mary, Islington
, on the 2nd of October, 1827 - she represented herself as a widow, by the name of
Sarah Webb
; I heard Mr. Webb was dead - I did not hear of the other husband; that she stated she had plenty of furniture, but I found none at all.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I am a Police-officer. I have the certificate of the two marriages; I took the prisoner at her brothers's house on the other side of Stepney church (certificate read).
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Confined Six Weeks .

2048.
SAMUEL ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October , 1 coat, value 12s.; 1 hat, value 8s.; 1 snuff-box, value 1s., and 1 pocket-book, value 1s. , the goods of
James Collins
.

ABRAHAM BARKER
. I keep the Bacchus, public-house at Hoxton
. I was in the skittle-ground
about five or six weeks back; Mr. Collins had been there two or three times; and that day he pulled off his coat and hat, left them in the Dutchpin box, and went into another ground; I heard a person had come over the wall; I went out and saw the prisoner; he gave these things into my arms and ran away; I had known him very well by his coming to the ground.

Prisoner. Q. What time was it? A. From half-past five to half-past six o'clock; it was between the lights - you threw the things into my arms - I did not stay three seconds; you are the person who gave them to me - I took them back to Mr. Collins; I did not see you again till you were at the office - it might be four or five weeks afterwards.

JAMES COLLINS
. I was at the skittle-ground on the 14th of October, and took off my coat and hat in the Dutchpin ground - I went to another ground, and heard a person drop off the wall on the other side; I looked, and missed my things - I had not seen the prisoner then, but Barker gave me my things; the coat had the pocket-book and snuff-box in the pocket.

JOHN FRYER
. The prisoner was described to me; I found him on the 15th of October in Hoxton - he ran away, and was stopped by another person; when I came up, he said, "Do you want me for the Bacchus job?" I said Yes.

Prisoner's Defence. I believe another officer can prove to the contrary; I never was in the skittle-ground that night - do you think, when he saw me only three seconds, and did not see me again for five weeks, he could know me again.?
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Nine Months ,

2049.
MARGARET BURNS
and
WILLIAM BURNS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of October , 3 pairs of shoes, value 7s. , the goods of
James Peart
.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 13th of October I saw the two prisoners near Peart's shop; I saw the woman go to the shop door with a knife, cut a string, and take down a pair of shoes - I went and took her, and found from sixty to one hundred duplicates on her, some for the prosecutor's property.

THOMAS SEABROOK
. I am a pawnbroker. I received two pairs of shoes from the female prisoner and her son, on the 29th of December and on the 23rd of September; the last were pawned by the woman - I cannot say who pawned the first.

DAVID JAMES
. I am in the service of Mr.
James Peart
, of Whitechapel
. These are all his property.

Margaret Burns
' Defence. I beg for mercy; my child is innocent - I have four children, and nothing to give them to eat.

MARGARET BURNS
-
GUILTY . Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Confined 14 Days .

WILLIAM BURNS
-
NOT GUILTY .

2050.
ALEXANDER JONES
and
THOMAS TOMPKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of October , 1 pair of trousers, value 12s. , the goods of
William Powell
.

GEORGE FROST
. I live with
William Powell
, a tailor , in Shoreditch
. On the 7th of October, between eight and ten o'clock he lost pair of trousers - they had been hanging inside his shop - a woman came in, and said a boy had run away with them; the officer came in a little after eleven, and asked if we had lost a pair of trousers.

THOMAS SHELSWELL
. On the 7th of October, about half-past ten o'clock in the forenoon, I was in Petticoat-lane with Lea; I saw the two prisoners together - one of them knew me and he hung back, but Jones came forward, and I saw he had something under his jacket; I stopped him, and told Lea to take the other - I asked Jones what he had got - he first of all said Nothing; I said, "It is rather bulky;" he then said, "A pair of trousers; "I said, "When did you get them;" he said either six weeks or six months ago, he bought them at Portsmouth; I took him into a public-house, and asked if there was any mark on them - he said No, not that he knew of; I found this mark on them, which led me to the prosecutor.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer, and took Tompkins.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Jones' Defence. A man asked me to buy them, and I gave 18s. for them; he said he brought them from Portsmouth six months ago.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

TOMPKINS -
NOT GUILTY .

2051.
CATHERINE CONNOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of October , 1 gown, value 1s. 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 3d.; 1 shawl, value 3d., and 1 hat, value 3s. , the goods of
Bridget Kelly
, widow .

BRIDGET KELLY
. I am a widow, and live in White Horse-alley, Cow-cross
. I have known the prisoner for several years; I let her sleep in my room on the 22d of October - I had not seen her for a long time; when she was gone I missed this property.

JOHN RICHMOND
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, in Christ Church-passage on the 22nd of October; she confessed she had robbed the woman - she had been to the overseer of the parish; I took her to the Compter, and found this shawl, shoes, stockings and the woman's cap on her, and these three duplicates.

GEORGE KNAPP
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a bonnet pawned on the 22nd of October - I gave this duplicate for it.

RICHARD EDWARD BARBER
. I have a petticoat pawned in the name of
Ann Connor
- I cannot swear by whom.

JOSEPH COLKETT
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown pawned by the prisoner.

BRIDGET KELLY
. These are my property; I was out at work, and when I came home they were gone.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the gown to take my shoes out of pawn - she had lent me these shoes till I got my own.
GUILTY . Aged 54.
Confined Twelve Months .

2052.
JANE DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of October , 3 1/2 yards of linen, value 2s. , the goods of
James Bowen
.

CHARLES SMITH
. I am a shopman to
James Bowen
, of Goswell-road
, a linen-draper . On the 26th of October, I heard a woman had taken something; I went into the street, and saw the prisoner running fast - I followed her, and near Sadler's-wells I took her, and taxed her with stealing the linen; she denied it, but I turned up her cloak and found it - it had been in the lobby of the shop.

JOHN MORGAN
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

2053.
GEORGE HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
George Pitt
.

ELIZABETH PITT. I am the wife of
George Pitt
, a shoemaker of Camden-town
. On the 8th of October, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was sitting behind the counter - the prisoner came, took these boots down, and looked at them as if he was going to purchase; he then looked up and down the street, folded them up, and walked off with them - I ran out, and cried Stop thief! I followed him till he was taken; he felt down on a heap of dirt, and then left the boots.

RICHARD FARRER
. I was washing a carriage, and saw the prisoner running; the witness and some others were pursuing - I jumped off, the prisoner fell down, and dropped the boots: I held him till the officer came.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

2054.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of September , 1 pair of clogs, value 5s. , the goods f
John Hudson
.

HUGH SPRING. I am a publican, and was passing Mr. Hudson's door on the 25th of September - I saw the prisoner at the window, and in five minutes I saw him comingout with a pair of clogs, which he put under his coat - I took him back.

GEORGE WOODGATE
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.

JOHN HUDSON. These are my clogs; I live in Featherstone-street, City-road
. I had seen them safe ten minutes before.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2055.
WILLIAM WALTHAM
and
JOSEPH PEACH
were indicated for
stealing, on the 25th of September
, 5 bushels of wheat, value 35s., and 2 sacks, value 3s. , the goods of
Edward Whalley
; and
ELIZABETH PIGGOTT
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen .

MR. BODKIN, who conducted the prosecution, declined offering any evidence against Elizabeth Piggott, who was here
acquitted .

EDWARD WHALLEY. I am a farmer , and live at South Mimms
. On the 25th of September I had fifteen loads of wheat in my barn, which had been dressed for market - there were some sacks of mine there; I saw the place secure at five o'clock - it was locked; I have seen some corn and sacks in the officer's hands; the sacks have my mark on them.

JOHN SIMKINS
. I am in Mr. Whalley's employ. I went to the barn on the 26th, in the morning - the door was open, and between five and six bushels of corn taken away, and two sacks; I have seen the sacks since, and knew them, and some corn which seemed to be the same.

BENJAMIN LAMBERT
. I am a smith. I was at South Mimms on Saturday, the 26th of September; I saw Waltham, Propstring, the officer, and Mr. Watch, at the Cross Keys - they then went to the cage. and left Waltham there for breaking Mr. Alderman Heygate's pales; I afterwards let Waltham out, and went with him to the house where
Elizabeth Piggott
and he lived together - Peach was there and Thomas, who is gone away; we had some gin, and all drank - then Peach and Thomas said they would go away; they packed up their clothes and went - I was coming out, and Waltham asked me to stop; I being tipsy did not stop - he said, "I have some wheat I want to move that came from Mr. Whalley's on Friday night;" and by his persuasion I helped to move it in a sack, that Piggott had in the house with some gleaning corn in it - I heard nothing about any other sacks; they said Peach and Thomas had brought it in two sacks - we took it across the road, and put it into Whittington's pond: the sack was taken back to the house - Piggott said they did it for fear they should get into trouble.
Prisoner Waltham. Q. Did not you come to the cage to me, and ask if I would come out? A.No.

WILLIAM HIGGS
. I am an officer. I went to Whittington's pond on the 27th of September; we found a great deal of wheat on the bridge and fence, and some in the pond - I found these two sacks under an arch, about a mile and a half from South Mimms; Waltham was in the cage, and the lock was broken: but he came back into the cage himself, as I was told - I went to him; he was quite tipsy - I asked who broke the lock of the cage; he said he could not tell - I went and took Peach at Biggleswade, at work at a blacksmith's shop; I said, "You are my prisoner" - he said, "Don't say any thing about it before these people; say it is for a little one;" and I said so - when we got out I told him it was for taking the wheat from Mr. Whalley's, and told him it would be better to speak the truth.

ELIZABETH PIGGOTT
. I was living at South Mimms. There was something brought to my house, but I cannot say what it was, nor who brought it - I was not at home.
COURT. Q. Was there a sack brought in? A. Yes, two - Peach and Thomas were there, but I cannot say whether they came before or afterwards, nor what time of night it was.
NOT GUILTY .

2056.
DAVID LYONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of October , 6 knives, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Saunders
.

THOMAS SAUNDERS
. I am a watchmaker , and keep a shop in Whitechapel-road
. On the 6th of October, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, I was standin the parlour, and saw the prisoner with his hand in a little glass-case in the shop - he took out six knives; he came in from the street - I did not know him before; I ran to the door - he was taken by an officer, and brought back; the tray was deficient of six knives.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Will you take upon yourself to swear the prisoner's arm was in the glass-case? A. Yes; I was six or eight feet from the place -I saw the prisoner in the shop, and he had his arms in the glass-case; he saw me, drew his arm back, and ran away - the prisoner is the person who took the knives - there were only this half dozen pen-knives; they were in the glass the night before, and the shop had not been opened, only the door - they were dropped at my door, and brought into my shop immediately; I never said the arm I saw in the glass-case I thought was my son's - I said I thought my son was in the shop, as I had just opened my street door, and then went into the parlour; at first I thought it was my son, but when I went to the door I saw she prisoner running - I was as quick in getting to the door as he was; it is a wide road.

ROBERT ROBERTS
. I was in Whitechapel-road on the 6th of October, early in the morning; I saw the prisoner running, and some persons after him - I saw Mr. Thompson stop him; I saw some knives in the road a minute or two after I saw the prisoner in the - they were place over which he had run - I did not take them up till he was stopped.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there a great many people? A. No, only one or two running after him - he did not turn any corners.

ANTHONY THOMPSON
. I saw the prisoner running, and secured him eighty or a hundred yards from the shop - he turned no corner; the knives were brought into the shop.

Prisoner's Defence. My master sent me to a marine-store shop in the Dog-row, and told me to make haste - I was running, the witness came, and took hold of me; Mr. Thompson took me back, and began searching me - he asked the prosecutor if he had lost any thing; he saidNo, and asked his son where the two gold watches were - he said up stairs; a person brought in the knives, and then I was taken to the watch-house - the prosecutor there said he saw some person in his shop, and he thought it was his son exposing goods for sale; the Magistrate asked him if he saw me take the knives - he said No, but he saw my arm in the window; I asked him why he did not attack me at the moment - he said he thought it was his son; I asked him again, and he said he did not want to be asked any questions by me - the Magistrate said I must tell a Jury that story.

ANTHONY THOPSON
re-examined. I believe he saw two persons in his shop and one ran one way and the other the other, and he thought one was his son - he first asked if the gold watches were safe; he did not then say any thing about his son.

THOMAS SAUNDERS
re-examined. Q. How long was it from first to last? A. I suppose not three minutes.
Cross-examined. Q. Were your shutters up? A. Yes, but the door was open, and it was sufficiently light for me to see the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

2057.
JANE RIDLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 blanket, value 5s. , the goods of
James Watt
.

JAMES WATT
. The prisoner had a room on the same floor as me. On the 12th of September my wife was out nursing, and I had to make my own bed - I went out, and put the key under the mat in case my wife should come home; when I came home I saw the bed clothes pulled about, and missed the blanket - there is no mark on this, but I had a pair of them, and this is the same as the other.

CHARLES WILLIAMSON
. This blanket was pawned with me by the prisoner, on the 12th of September, about twelve or one o'clock.
Prisoner's Defence. That man has sworn false - I came home, took my own blanket, and pawned it for 2s.; he has owed me a great animosity for some time, because I said he brought in women of a night.

JAMES WATT
re-examined. Q. Did she complain of you for bringing women to the house? A. No; I never had any one there but my wife; I have lived with Mr. Burgin eleven years - the man she lives with is not her husband; she came up to me for a light when they came there, and I said to my wife, "I don't like these people, for I heard him beat her, and she threatened to hang him;" I never spoke to her but once in anger, when she was coming up- I told her to keep her distance; I am sure my blanket was gone.

CHARLES WILLIAMSON
re-examined. Q. Did she say before the Magistrate it was her own? A. Yes; she has not often pawned blankets, but I have known her these twenty years, and never knew any thing wrong of her.
NOT GUILTY .

2068.
ANN RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of October , 1 bolster, value 6d.; 1 blanket, value 6d.; 1 sheet, value 1s., and 3 yards of carpet, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Clark
.

ELIZABETH CLARK
. I am a widow . The prisoner lodged with me for three weeks, till the 18th of October, in Cow-lane, New Gravel-lane
- it was a furnished room; I did not know she was going. On the 19th of October I took my child to school; when I returned there was no one in the house - I missed the articles stated.

CHRISTOPHER GREEN
. I took the prisoner on the 19th of October - I found 12s. 8d. on her, and a duplicate of a bed pawned for 14s.

JAMES WAYLING
. I am a Police-officer. The prisoner was brought to our office; I asked what had become of the things - she told me she had taken them to Bluegate-fields, and sold them; I went there, and found all but the bolster-case.

EDWARD EDMOND CHILD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in High-street, Shadwell. I have a bed, but the person who took it in is out of town; I have seen the prisoner at my master's.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not tell the officer I had sold them; I said I had left them for a few halfpence - she gave me leave to take any thing I liked, as she knew the distress I was in.

ELIZABETH CLARK
. How could I do so? I never did.

JAMES WAYLING
. She told me she left them at a house a Jew lives in, who I knew took in such things; I went and asked for them - they were delivered up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Six Weeks .

2059.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of September , 1 jacket, value 5s.; 1 shilling, and 1 halfpenny , the property of
Diedirick Klinck
.

DIEDIRICK KLINCK. I am a German. On the 28th of September I was at the King Harry, in Red Lion-street, Whitechapel
, about ten o'clock at night; there was fiddling up stairs - I went up; a man put his hand into my pocket, and took my money - I caught hold of him, and several of them beat me; the landlord came up, and took me down - I said I would not go without that man; they came down, and said I should fight, and they would give me fair play - I pulled off my jacket, and the prisoner was taken with it.

GEORGE HEARNE
. I am a watchman. I produce the jacket which I took from the prisoner - this shilling and this halfpenny were in the pocket; I was going to cry ten o'clock, saw the row, and the prisoner was running from the crowd with it in his hand - he turned the corner and I caught him; I asked him how he came by it - he at first said it was his own, and then said it was the man's who was fighting, and he was going to take it home to his wife; I took him to the watch-house, then went to the crowd, and brought the prosecutor, who claimed it.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the jacket half a dozen doors from where they were fighting.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

2060.
SARAH SHARP
and
ELIZABETH RYAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of October , 1 watch, value 70s., and 1 watch-chain, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Brockman
, from his person .

HENRY BROCKMAN. I am a porter . On the 9th ofOctober, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Long-lane; the two prisoners and another woman came up, and asked me to give them something to drink, which I did, at a wine-vaults, and we walked on to Chequer-ally
- they then fell upon me, and Ryan took my watch from my fob; Sharpe held me while Ryan handed the watch to another, who ran away - I held Ryan till the watchman came, and took her; I am quite sure of their person - I was with them about half an hour.

Prisoner Ryan. Q. Were you not drinking with three men, in a court? A. There were two men with me, and we had one pot of beer; there was no woman with me - I did not say to you."I have treated this woman, and now I will treat you."
COURT. Q. Where were you going? A. I had a window sash to carry to Clerkenwell-green - they went with me there, and on my return robbed me.
Prisoner Ryan. Q. Did you not ask me to go to Clerkenwell, I refused, and you said you had no more money, till you had been there? A. No, I did not - I was not in any private house with a woman.

GEORGE HOOKER
. I am a watchman. On the evening of the 9th of October, about half-past nine o'clock, I heard a cry of Watch! I went up to the place, and saw the prosecutor and Ryan together - he said he had lost his watch, and Ryan had robbed him of it; he said there three women had been, and they had collared him like a bull dog - I took Ryan to the watch-house.

THOMAS EARLE
. I am headborough. I was at the watch-house, and saw Ryan brought in; I then went with the prosecutor and an officer, to the Salmon and Ball, Salmon and Ball-court, Bunhill-row - I said, "Look round, and see if there is any body you know; "he pointed out Sharpe - I took her into custody; she seemed to refuse to come, but I said, "You must come - the man says you are the person; "She then came - the prosecutor was sober.

EDWARD HANDS
. I am a headborough. I was in a public-house three days after, and heard some girls say the chain was found by Britt - I knew him, and went and got it.

JAMES BRITT
. I got this chain from my wife, and gave it to the officer.

ELLEN BRITT
. I found this chain in Chequer-alley on the 10th of October; I shewed the place to the officer.

EDWARD HANDS
. I went to the place where she said she found it, and it was close to the place where the prosecutor stated he was robbed.
Sharpe's Defence. I went to the Salmon and Ball, to get my husband home; he was out, and I waited - the officer and the prosecutor came in, and they said I must go with them.

Ryan's Defence. I was coming across Smithfield, and saw the prosecutor drinking with three men and a woman; he gave me some gin, and asked how far I was going - I said to Bunhill-row; he refused to go with me- I went home, then went out, and passed Chequer-alley, where I saw him; he took hold of me, and said I had robbed him.

ISABELLA SAWYER
. I live at No. 2, Chequer-alley. I was with Ryan, on the 9th of October, from half-past seven o'clock, till she was taken - she was not out of my sight; we had taken a walk together, after I had done work she then went with me to my own room, and staid three quarters of an hour - we then went out again; I heard the cry of Watch! - I turned and saw the prosecutor with his small-clothes down, in a very indecent manner; he took hold of her, and said, "You have got my watch" - she said, "Nonsense man;" he let her go, and then took her again; I had not seen the prosecutor drinking.

JAMES CANNON
. I am a labourer, and have lived at No. 4, Chequer-alley, about eight months; I never saw the prisoners, but the prosecutor came to my house, with a girl, as near as I can guess about half-past eight o'clock that night - I had just come home from my work, at Mr. Garrett's, an oil-man, in Whitecross-street; I had not been in two minutes, when the prosecutor came in, and went up stairs - he had not been there three minutes, when he came down again; the young woman then came down, and bade me good night - I said to her, "It is strange that a man should come to a house of this kind, and not pay for it;" I looked out, and he turned to the right hand - the girl went after him, and he followed her up; I went it, sat down, and in a few minutes, I heard Watch! cried - I went out, and saw the prosecutor running with his trousers down; he caught hold of Ryan, and said, "You have robbed me of my watch" - "No(says she) I have not;" "You d - d b - h, you have, (says he) and I have got hold of you;" I did not take any part in it, nor ask him for any thing for my room - I thought it very indecent for any man to do a thing of that kind.

GEORGE HOOKER
re-examined. Q.How near were you, when the cry of Stop thief! was raised? A. About six doors; the prosecutor's clothes were up - Ryan said nothing about any indecent attack upon her; she only said she would go to the watch-house.

HENRY BROCKMAN
. I did not go to any house with any young woman; my trousers were not down at all - I am married.
Prisoner Ryan. He is sure not to own it, because his wife is in Court.

SHARPE -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

RYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .

2061.
CHARLOTTE STROUD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 44 sovereigns, and 6 half-sovereigns , the monies of
Joseph Singer
.

JOSEPH SINGER. I am a currier . On the 15th of October, I went to Drury-lane Theatre, with a friend; I got tipsy - Stephens, the officer, took me to some watch-house, and I left there fifty-nine sovereigns in a bag, in the care of the inspector of the Police - I then had three or four shillings in my pocket; I met the prisoner that night, went home and slept with her, at No. 7, Earl-street
- the next day she went with me to the watch-house, and waited outside, while I got my sovereigns, and took some things out of pawn for her; we then went up to the Regent's-park, and to the Zoological-gardens - we had something to eat and drink, and came home to her house again; Mrs. Lloyd was with us - I sent for two bottles of sherry, and one of port; Mrs. Lloyd saw my money - it was in a bed-room; Lloyd went home about ten o'clock - I then locked the door; the prisoner and Iwent to bed - she had put something into the wine, that made me rather drowsy; I did not see her do it, but I think there must have been something - I put my trousers under my head, with forty-seven sovereigns in them; in the morning about half-past six o'clock, a person came and called Charlotte - that awoke me, and when I roused up, my money was all gone, and my trousers were on the bed; I recollect her lying down the night before, but whether her clothes were off, I do not know - I was quite sensible when I put my money into my trousers pocket, and when I went to bed.

Prisoner. Q. Can you say that I took the money from you? A. I can only say that I locked the door myself; no one could come in, and it was half open in the morning - there was a lock on the door; there had been a padlock on it, and I told the landlord, if he did not put a proper lock on, I would not stay.

SAMUEL STEPHENS
. I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor one evening, tipsy at Drury-lane theatre; he stated he had a great many sovereigns - I took him down stairs, and gave him to two Police-constables.

SARAH LLOYD
. My husband is a cabinet-maker. I went to the room where the prisoner and the prosecutor were; at half past eight o'clock that evening, the prisoner met me on the stairs, and asked me to go to her place; I did - there was some wine on the table; the prosecutor offered me a glass, and I drunk it - the prisoner then fetched a bottle of sherry; it was ten minutes past ten, when I came away - I saw the prosecutor have a bag of sovereigns, and he gave her half a sovereign, to fetch the wine; I said "You had better put your money into your bag, and take care of it" - I asked the prisoner her motive for giving him so much wine; she said, "That is to myself, Mrs. Lloyd; "I wished them good night, and when I came out, some one locked the door - the prisoner left me with him while she went for a bottle of wine- he gave me some wine to take to my husband, who was ill; I saw the prisoner offer the prosecutor a glass of wine, while he laid on the bed, which he refused for some time, but she urged it on him, and he took it - I saw the prisoner at Bow-street.

MARY CHERRY
. The prisoner lodged in my house. I saw the prosecutor in her room on Friday; and on the following morning about two o'clock, I saw the prisoner, who said she wanted something to drink, and asked me if I thought she could get it - I said I did not know, without it was at the watering-house: she said she wanted change for a sovereign, and she thought she could not get it there - she went away from my room, and went along the passage with a candle; I did not see her again, but in the morning I saw the prosecutor go out with two Police-men - the prisoner left me, I think, last Saturday three weeks.

SARAH ALLINGTON
. I live in Church-street, Bethnal-green - my husband is a dealer in marine-stores. At six o'clock in the morning, last Saturday three weeks, the prisoner came to my place - I had seen her but once before; she came in a cabriolet - she came to take farewell of me, and said she was going into the country to her friends; I saw some gold in a paper, but I do not know how much - she said it was money which had been left her by her brother; she asked my advice as to what she should do - I advised her to clothe herself genteely, and go to service; I went with her, and purchased a purse and a variety of other things - she stopped with me till last Monday fortnight, and then went put out to take a walk; while she was gone I heard a person had lost some money - I was afraid it was her, and advised her to leave my place at night.

SAMUEL STEPHENS
. I took up the prisoner on Wednesday, the 21st of October, I believe - I found her in Shoreditch; I had heard of the robbery a few days before - I told her I was a Bow-street officer, and took her for taking the sovereigns from Singer; she was surprised, and said she knew nothing of it - I took her into a public-house, and found half a crown and some halfpence upon her; she said it was no interest to me to take her to Bow-street, and a friend of hers would let me have 5l. to let her go - I took her to the watch-house, and the next morning before the Magistrate; I asked what she had done with her luggage - she said it was gone to the Saracen's Head to go to Bristol, but from further inquiries I found her things at the Bell and Mackarel, Mileend-road; there was a bed, a blanket, a counterpane, some black stuff, some calico, a bonnet, and a veil which appeared new, or nearly so, a box, and two hat boxes - in the box was a phial with some stuff in it; I took it to a chemist's, and they said it was sugar of lead, and shewed me the effect of it on pewter - I only knew it was her box by what I was told.
Prisoner. Mrs. Allington's brother carried the things there - the stuff in the phial was for an inflammation; I could take you to the surgeon who gave it to me - Mrs. Allington knows who it was.

SARAH ALLINGTON
. She went out one morning to get some medicine - my brother Philip went with her; I saw her bring in a small phial, and she took a tea-spoonful of the stuff - her box went from my place to the Bell and Mackarel.

WILLIAM LIVERMORE
. I took some things by the prisoner's directions, but I cannot tell the day.
The prisoner handed in a written defence, simply declaring her innocence.
GUILTY (of stealing only.) Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

2062.
JOHN ASHFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 3 candlesticks, value 3s. , the goods of
James Eastmead
.

JAMES EASTMEAD
. I keep a public-house in Bedfordbury
. I lost three candlesticks on the 12th of September from my parlour - the prisoner had been there, and had a glass of porter, which I took in; when he was gone I missed them - I saw one of them again in about three minutes; it was taken on the prisoner by a person who is not here now, and brought back.

WILLIAM PARKER
. I am a constable. I have two candlesticks, which I got at a shop where the prisoner said he had sold them, in White Hart-yard, Drury-lane.

BENJAMIN WARWICK
. I live in White Hart-yard. The prisoner brought these candlesticks to me, and said they were two his mother gave him to sell.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I leave my case to your mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor, having heard a good character.
Confined Six Months .

2063.
THOMAS HAINES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of October , 2 hats, value 10s. , the goods of
Charles Cockburn
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

2064.
WILLIAM WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of October , 2 sheets, value 6s. , the goods of
James Stevens
.

JAMES STEVENS. I keep the Coach and Horses, at Tottenham
. The prisoner came to my house and slept on Friday night last - he left at half-past six o'clock in the morning and I missed the sheets; I followed him and said he had some sheets of mine - he said, "I have, and will go back;" I took him back, and found these round his middle.

JOSEPH FORRESTER
. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. It was distress made me do it.
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Three Months .

2065.
ABRAHAM DEATH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of October , 1 time-piece, value 40s. , the goods of
Daniel Deacon
, the elder
, and others.

CHARLES TWIST
. I am in the service of
Daniel Deacon
, the elder, and his two sons, at the White Horse, Cripplegate. On the 27th of October, I was told there was a time-piece missing from the budget of a waggon, which went from there on the Saturday, to go to Cambridge, and returned on the Monday; this is the timepiece - it has the name of Deacon on it.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a waggoner. I came with the waggon from Buntingford last Monday - the time-piece was safe at six o'clock, and when we got to London I missed it; I took the prisoner up on the road out of charity, as he said he had no money, and brought him to Stamford-hill.

JOSEPH FOX
. I am the guard of the waggon. The prisoner was taken up out of charity, and sat on the front of the waggon, by the time-piece, which hung in a leather budget in front.

GEORGE WILLMOTT
. The prisoner and the time-piece were given to me by Fox - the prisoner cried, and seemed sorry.

JOSEPH FOX
. The prisoner told us where he was apprentice - we went there, and found where his father lived; he was at home having his breakfast on the Tuesday morning - we called him to the door, and asked him for it; he denied it twice, and then said he had given it to his sister - he sent her for it, and gave it us.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2066.
JOHN BEDFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 4 live tame fowls, price 10s. , the property of
William Williams
.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I live at the Bell, at Ealing
, and keep fowls - they were safe on Wednesday morning at seven o'clock, and in the evening at seven I missed four; I have known the prisoner ten years - he is a drover , and has passed and called at my house; he lives in London - I have seen my fowls since, and knew them; they were then dead.

GEORGE GODDARD
. I was going across Ealing-common with two men that evening; we saw the prisoner lying on the common, and we called him - he got up, and walked on towards Acton; we saw something at the place he had been at, and went and found four fowls - the feathers were picked off one, and being white we saw them; I sent the two men after the prisoner - he said he found them there.

JOSEPH SMITH
. I am a constable. The prisoner was put into my custody - I shewed the fowls to Mr. Williams, who owned them.

Prisoner's Defence. I had called at the prosecutor's house that morning, and had 1 1/2d. of gin; I was going across the common at half-past six o'clock, and there was something white; my dog saw it first, and put his nose close to me, as much as to say, "Master, come" - I went and found the fowls; I said, "They don't belong to me, "and I did not touch them - I was going on to Acton, and they took me.

GEORGE GODDARD
re-examined. He was lying down on the ground, and when he got up we saw the fowls - it was rather dark; the fowl that was plucked seemed to have been done with the hand, and they were quite warm.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Two Months .

2067.
JOHN SORLTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 12 pieces of stained paper, value 3l. 16s. , the goods of
Jeffery Jolly
.

JEFFERY JOLLY. I am a paper-stainer , and live in Marylebone
. I have known the prisoner in the trade - he came to me on the 15th of September, and said he had a job for a gentleman who had sold his house, and must have it papered immediately, and wanted some patterns; I gave him some - he came the next day, and said the gentleman had selected one - I gave him to understand there would be no credit; I called one of my lads, and told him to take the papers to the gentleman, but not leave them without the money; I gave him a receipt - the prisoner said the gentleman's name was Sorlter, and his own name was
John Brown
.

WILLIAM COOPER
. I was sent by the prosecutor on the 15th of September, with twelve pieces of paper; he told me not to leave them without the money - I went with the prisoner, and when we got to the house he said he had known Mr. Jolly many years, and he would call in the evening and pay the money; I left the paper in the kitchen.

JOHN GRINDLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three pieces of paper, pawned by the prisoner on the 16th of September, in the name of John Sorlter.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found three rooms had been papered with this paper, at No. 1, Grosvenor-place, Chelsea, where the witness took them, and these three pieces were pawned at Chelsea.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner. He saw the wife of the person it was forcome up stairs with a child in her arms; here is the bill of parcels the prosecutor gave me - I was obliged to make away with the rest of it, as Mr. Kenyon was not at home.

JEFFERY JOLLY
. This bill was made out for the gentleman he stated it was for - I went to the house, and the woman refused to tell me any thing about the prisoner - I understand he has been paid for it.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Four Months .
OLD COURT.
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 3.
First London Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2068.
EDWARD BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Roberts
, from his person .

ROBERT ROBERTS. I am a wine-merchant . On the 14th of October, about half-past six o'clock, I was in St. Paul's church-yard
; I felt a tug at my pocket, and a hand in it; I turned round, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand; I saw him give it to a person, who ran away with it - I seized the prisoner, and gave him in charge; he resisted, and tried to get away.

Prisoner. Q.Did you not say a young woman told you I had the handkerchief? A. One came up, and said she saw you take it, but I saw it in your hand; he struggled very much, and I lost sight of the woman.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2069.
GEORGE CARMAN
was indicted for that
he, on the 29th of September , at St. Botolph, without, Bishopsgate
, having in his custody and possession, a bill of exchange, which is as follows:- £47: 0: 0 Barming, September 18th, 1829. Two months after date, pay to my order, the sum of forty-seven pounds; value received.
GEORGE CARMAN
. To Mr.
James Ellis
, Barming, Kent. upon which said bill of exchange, was written a certain false, forged, and counterfeited acceptance of the said bill of exchange, which said false, forged, and counterfeited acceptance, is as follows:- "Exceped,
James Ellis
, payable at the George Inn, Boro;" he, the said
George Carman
, afterwards, on the same day, at the same parish, feloniously did utter, and publish as true, the said forged acceptance, knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud
Isaac Dimsdale Child
.

SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating the prisoner's intent to be to defraud
James Ellis
.

ISAAC DIMSDALE CHILD. I am a wine and spirit-merchant , and live at No. 199 Bishopsgate-street, without; I do not know what trade the prisoner is - he has formerly been a publican; I do not know where he lived - I knew him when he kept a public-house in Old-street road; he called at my house the day before the time in question, and has for some time called at my house, I suppose, every day - there was nothing remarkable in his calling. On Tuesday the 29th of September, about ten o'clock in the morning, he came to me, and said he had a bill, which he wished to have discounted, drawn on Mr. James Ellis, of Barming, in Kent; he stated that he had known
James Ellis
from a boy, that they were brought up together at school, at Burwash - I asked him if it was Mr.
James Ellis
, the large hop grower; he said Yes, and that he had street to Mr. Ellis that he was about to take a public-house, and that Mr. Ellis told him he would accommodate him with any sum under 100l.; - that he might draw on him to any amount under 100l.; he then put this bill into my hands - I immediately noticed to him the word "Exceped" across it, instead of accepted; he said that did not matter, the bill was as safe, as the Bank of England, all the same for that, and it did not matter about being altered - he then asked me what money I could let him have immediately on it, as he wanted some immediately to buy some clothes; I told him I was then short of cash, but what I had in the house he should have- he asked me to let him have 2l.; I gave him a sovereign and twenty shillings, and then sent my brother over to the George inn, where the bill was made payable to make the necessary inquiry - my brother had gone before the prisoner went away, but I believe he did not know the bill was out of my hands; I advanced him 10s., more after my brother had left - my brother was gone four hours, or nearly so; the prisoner remained in my house I should think half or three quarters of an hour after my brother was gone - I do not think he knew my brother was gone on this errand, for he went out at the side door; I did not tell him my brother was gone - he came again in the evening, for some more money, I suppose, as I had appointed to let him have more that night or the next morning - on his coming, in consequence of something my brother said I had the prisoner taken.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. What is your brother? A. He has only lately come from sea; he is a seafaring young man - he does not lodge with me; he has been from sea three months or nearly so, and has not employ at present - I am a publican; I have sold horses on commission - I kept livery stables seven years ago; I never dealt in horses with the prisoner; - I advanced the 40s. after the bill was shown to me; I had no previous meeting with him on that day, before the bill was produced - there was nothing to cause any suspicion on my mind about the bill till I saw it, and then the only suspicion was from the word exceped; knowing Mr. Ellis to he a man of opulence I thought he must know how to spell.

Q.Did you not, in the first instance. propose yourself to discount the bill? A. I said I would advance him the money on it - he said he did not want the whole immediately; I was not the first to propose it - he asked if I would advance him a little, and more as he wanted it; I do not think he had seen my brother - he might have seen him in the shop, but he went into the back room; it is very likely he may have seen him on the premises - after he was gone the prisoner asked for 10s. more; I advanced it - he saw my brother in the evening when he was taken; I do not know whether they recognized each other: 50s. is all I advanced on this bill - I have been kind to him in other instance.

DANIEL SPENCER CHILD
. I am the prosecutor's brother. I was in the shop when the prisoner came in, but in a minute after I went into the back room; the prisoner saw me - I had seen him before in my brother's shop, drinking liquor; I had been at his house six or sevenyears ago - I had no intimacy with him; (looking at the bill) my brother gave me this bill to make inquiry about it; I went to the George inn, Borough, and in consequence of that inquiry I returned the bill to my brother - the prisoner was not there when I returned: I waited a long time to see Mr. Schofield the proprietor of the George.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you met the prisoner, did not you, afterwards? A. No; I met him out of doors the morning before, and he told me he was going to get a bill which he had got in the Borought, and which he was going to ask my brother to lend him some money on, or to discount it, I cannot say which - I was going into Tooley-street, and walked with him; he did not request me to walk with him - he went with me to a house in Tooley-street, where he drank with me; I did not see him in the after part of the day, till he was taken - my brother's is a gin shop.

COURT. Q.Where did you separate after coming out of the house in Tooley-street? A. Not till we got into Bishopsgate-street again; he turned up a turning in Tooley-street away from me - I waited for him till he returned; he then walked back with me to my brother's.

WESTERMAN SCHOFIELD
. I keep the George inn, Borough; there is no other George there - I am acquainted with Mr.
James Ellis
; he is a large farmer and hop grower - I have known him for years, and am acquainted with his hand-writing perfectly well; I have seen him write, and have known his writing many years (looking at the bill) - I am perfectly satisfied this acceptance is not his hand-writing, nor any thing like it.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen him write? A. Yes, for many years, as well as seen his writing; he used my house many years, sometimes two or three times a week - he lives at Barming, in Kent; I know his son who lives in a neighbouring parish - his name is James Day Ellis.

MR. JAMES ELLIS. I have no second Christian name,(Looking at the bill) the name "
James Ellis
" here is not my hand-writing, nor in the least like it - mine is rather a particular signature; I know no other James Ellis at Barming - my son did live there once, but not at that time: his name is
James Johnson Ellis
- it is not his writing; I never authorized any one to put my name to such a bill as this - I have no knowledge of the prisoner, and do not recollect that I ever went to school with him; I recollect the name in the parish when I was a boy - I have looked at the prisoner, but do not recollect him; I certainly recollect his brother or a person of his name. but I certainly did not know there was such a man - as far as I have any knowledge I have not known him since I was a boy; I do not remember having been at school with him - if I was I have not kept up any intimacy with him; I did not know there was such a man in existence.

Cross-examined. Q. You are not altogether a stranger to the family; you knew the prisoner? A. I knew there was such a man in the parish of Burwash once, and that his brother has been in my employ; it could easily be discovered that the acceptance was not mine, it is not at all like mine.
COURT. Q. You never authorized the brother to sign your name? A. No.(The bill was here put in and read.)

Prisoner's Defence. (written.) My Lord and Gentlemen of the Jury, - Confident of your patient hearing, I will briefly state the cause which has placed me before you in so critical a situation. My life is in your hands; but I am persuaded, that if any favourable circumstances have transpired during my trial I shall have the benefit of them. The evidence on the part of the prosecution you have heard. I most solemnly declare that I was quite ignorant of the bill being a forged instrument. I was about taking a public house at Deptford; I became possessed of the bill in the following manner: - Smith, formerly a customer of mine, (and now I believe he goes to and fro in the country with fruit) was aware, that I was going into business, he requested me to draw up a bill for two months, and he would get it accepted by a friend of his who would honor it when due; so indifferent was I to what he proposed, that I forgot the circumstance altogether, till, unfortunately for me, I must Smith again: he presented a bill to me drawn for two months, and requested me to put my name, saying he would get it accepted and bring it back again. I did so, and it was brought again to me. My Lord and Gentlemen, is it likely? was it the conduct of a man in his senses to have a bill by me which I knew to be a forgery? and knowing of the fatal consequences resulting from committing the crime of forgery, should I have gone to a person, who has known me for so many years? rather, should I not have applied to have it cashed by a person who would not so easily have detected me; would I, after obtaining 2l. on that bill, have returned to the prosecutor, and that after a lapse of upwards of three hours, having given the said bill into his possession, and receiving 10s. more? I left his house, was absent about half an hour, and returned once more to his house, when I was apprehended on a charge of forgery, without the least inquiry being made as to whether the person who was said to have accepted the bill was a responsible person or not. My Lord and Gentlemen, I do not hesitate to say, that it was a vile conspiracy against me for my destruction. I will briefly state the circumstances, and leave the rest to your deliberate consideration. I called at the prosecutor's house and had something to drink; the prosecutor then asked me what he should lend me on that bill, as he could do some good with it. I told him I did not immediately want money; he however persuades me to take 2l., and sends me after the bill - on my road to fetch it, his brother way-lays me, and never leaves me till I am taken into custody. My Lord and Gentlemen, I beseech you most earnestly, that as my reputation amongst society, nay, my life is now at stake, and entirely depending on your verdict, I feel confident that you will give it every consideration that the nature of my case requires; and I aver, that which ever way this investigation may terminate, I am entirely innocent of the crime laid to my charge. I feel assured, after a candid and conscientious inquiry into the evidence, you will return a verdict in favour of the unfortunately person who now addresses you.
MR. CHILD. I know the prisoner's hand-writing; the signature

"
George Carman
" to the bill is his writing.
Seven witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 45.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury, on account of his good character.

2070.
HENRY MORTIMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of September , at Christchurch, 2 silver watches, value 6l.; 1 seal, value 10s., and 1 gold ring, value 2l., the goods of
James Drake
, in his dwelling-house .

JAMES DRAKE
. I live in Crispin-street, Spitalfields
, in the parish of Christchurch, and am a watch-gilder ; I keep the house. The prisoner came to me as a lodger on the 26th of September - he had one room on the second floor,as a single man; I keep my watches in drawers on the ground floor. On the 30th of September, about two o'clock, I went to see what the time was, and found every thing correct in the drawer; I shut the drawer and the door of the room, but did not lock it - I saw the prisoner in the shop between four and five o'clock; he said he wanted to write a letter to send to Portsmouth, to his father - I keep a chandler's-shop ; the watches were in my bed-room- the prisoner had slept at home every night till then, but did not on that night; I went to the drawer about half-past seven o'clock that evening, and missed two silver watches, they were fairly worth from 3l. to three guineas each, at least, and a chain to each watch - a gold mourning-ring, worth from 38s., to 2l. - I gave 38s. for it at a jeweller's shop; it weighed 5 1/2 dwts., and a seal worth 10s.; in consequence of the prisoner saying he was writing to his father at Portsmouth. I went down there about the 17th or 18th of October, and found him at his father's house: I gave him into custody, and had him brought here - (looking at a watch produced by Wild) this is one of the watches I lost, and the chain to it; I have had the watch about eighteen months; I am not the maker - it is my own gilding; I am quite sure of it - there is no maker's name on it; it was in this state when I lost it.

ROBERT WILD
. I am shopman to Mr. Sowerby, a pawnbroker, of Chiswell-street. I received this watch in pawn from the prisoner on the 30th of September, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, and lent him 30s. on it; I never saw him before, but am quite certain of his person - I gave him what I supposed amounted to 30s.; he came next morning, and said I had given him a 7s. piece instead of a half-sovereign - I said, "I gave it you for the watch you pawned last night, did not I?" he said Yes, and I gave him half a sovereign for it - I am quite certain of him.

JOSHUA ARMSTRONG
. I am an officer of Worship-street. I went to Portsmouth, and took the prisoner.
Prisoner. Armstrong knows my character. Witness. His father has been forty-two years in His Majesty's dockyard at Portsmouth, and has been a very respectable man.
Prisoner. My friends are all at Portsmouth.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 22.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

2071.
WILLIAM CLEGG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , at Paddington, 1 watch, value 20l; 1 seal, value 1l.; 1 brooch, value 10s.; 4 rings, value 2l.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 10s.; 1 spoon, value 10s., and 40 herrings, value 5s., the goods of
Alexander Cabbell Mann
, in his dwelling-house .

CAROLINE COURTNEY MANN
. I am the wife of
Alexander Cabbell Mann
, who is a fishmonger - we live in Connaught-terrace, Edgware road
, in the parish of Paddington. The prisoner was about three weeks in our employ - he had been in service before he came to us; he did not sleep in our house, but came in the day time. On the 4th of September he came as usual a little after seven o'clock; I let him in at the private door, and desired him to go down into the kitchen and light the fire - I went down into the kitchen with him, and the watch was hanging over the dresser; it was a gold watch - I had hung it there a quarter of an hour before - I left him in the kitchen, and went down again to see the time at twenty minutes to eight o'clock, and the watch hung there then, and he was there; I went up stairs to call my husband and children, and when I came down he had opened the shop door, and was gone; I had told him not to open the shop door - I missed the watch, also a gold brooch from up stairs in the bed-room; he could not have taken that that morning, but it was safe the morning before; I also missed four rings from a drawer in the bedroom, and a silver table-spoon and sugar-tongs from the same place; there was a seal to the watch: about forty herrings were taken from the shop - I had seen them that morning: I have never seen the things since - I inquired about at the pawnbrokers in the neighbourhood. I never saw the prisoner again till the 23rd of October, when I found him in a cart at Kensington gravel-pits; my husband was with me, and took him.

GEORGE WATTS
. I know the prisoner - I have seen him about Kensington gravel-pits; I first saw him about the 7th of September, and have played about there with him - I have seen him with two or three sovereigns; we used to ask him how he got them, and he said he lived at a bonnet-shop in Regent-street three years - that his master never paid him regularly, and when he did he paid him as much as seven sovereigns.

MRS. MANN re-examined. He came into our service from Mr. Plummer, a hosier, of Regent-street, but we took him on his mother's recommendation, and did not see Plummer. The watch was gold, and worth 20l.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 15.

Before Mr.
Baron Garrow
.

2072.
JOSEPH MOGGERIDGE
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Ward
, on the 14th of October , and stealing 2 jugs, value 1s. 6d.; 2 dishes, value 9d.; 4 plates, value 8d.; 2 saucers, value 2s., and 21 penny-pieces, his property .

MARGARET WARD. I am nine years old, and live with my father, James Ward, in Whitecross-street
. On the 14th of October I was alone in the house, I shut the street door, left it on the latch, and went out into the back yard; I remained there about a quarter of an hour, then came back, and saw a little boy run out - I did not see whether he had any thing, now hear any noise; I had time to see him; I had never seen him before - I missed some Delphware from the cupboard, and some halfpence in a little bag, which was in a mug - I went and told my mother almost directly; she was in Whitecross-street, selling fruit: I then got a constable, and went to Moggeridge's father's house, which is next door but one to us - the constable knocked at the door; it was not opened - he got in at the window, and let me in; this was within ten minutes of the time, but nothing was found - the prisoner is not the boy who ran out; he was much less than him: he told the Magistrate the door was kept fast because his father expected an execution; I am quite sure he is not the boy, for I knew the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. Fifth Day.
Third Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2073.
WILLIAM PILBEAM
was indicted for
stealing,on the 17th of September , 1 pair of sheets, value 20s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 4s., and 1 medal, value 4s. , the goods of
George Ross
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

2074.
JAMES PARSONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 1 waistcoat, value 4s. , the goods of
Abraham Solomon
.

ABRAHAM SOLOMON. I am a clothes-dealer . On the 28th of October, while I was at a neighbour's, this waistcoat was taken from my shop; I saw it at Eagle-street watch-house, and know it - I had seen it safe half an hour before.

JAMES ISAAC
. I saw the prisoner running up Hatton-wall - I came up to him, and he was going to throw this waistcoat down an area; he was about three hundred yards from Solomon's - I took him to the watch-house; the prosecutor came, and said if it was his there was a figure of 8 on the collar, and there is one; the prisoner said he found it in the middle of Great Saffron-hill.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Saffron-hill. and saw a young man running, who I suppose dropped it; I was running away with it, and was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

2075.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of October , 1 shawl, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Smale
.

RICHARD SMALE. I keep a coffee-room . On the 24th of October my wife came in and threw this shawl across the wainscot, and went up stairs; the prisoner was there, and called for a cup of coffee - he drank part of it, and went out suddenly; in less than five minutes my wife missed her shawl: on Friday last she saw him in the street, and brought him home - I questioned him about it; he at first denied it - I told him I thought it was his first offence, and he did it through distress, and if he could tell me where I could go for a good character, I would be as lenient as I could with him - he said he did it through distress, and he worked at a dyer's near Finsbury-square.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I have a shawl, pawned on Saturday week, by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I took it up, as I thought there had been some woman in the place; the prosecutor said if I would give it up, he would not appear against me.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Month .

2076.
SUSAN SURETEES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of October , 3 pairs of leather soles, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
Eusebius Smith
.

JOHN ANDREW COTTON
. I am shopman to Mr. Eusebias Smith, a leather-cutter , of Kingsland-road
. Last Saturday the prisoner came and bought a pair of soles, which she paid for, then stooped down, and put these three pairs into her basket, and then the pair she had bought - she was going out; I told her Mr. Smith wanted a word with her, and I rang the bell for Mr. Smith - she found there was something amiss, and went to take the soles out of the basket; she took out two pairs; I said."That will not do - you must let me look into the basket; "Mr. Smith said he would send for an officer, for she had been doing it some time; these three pairs of soles were taken from her basket - she said she was very sorry.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am a constable. I went to the shop- the prisoner was delivered to me, with these three pairs of soles; she begged forgiveness.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I deny putting any into the basket - I looked out some, and gave the witness to put by for me till I returned; I had not put them into the basket, and he knows it well.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined Six Months .

2077.
ANN MORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 blanket, value 2s., and 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
Dennis Slater
.

MARY SLATER
. I am the wife of Dennis Slater - we live in St. Giles'
. On the 10th of October the prisoner, who had lodged with me about a month, left - I missed a sheet and a blanket; she came to my house this day week, and was intoxicated - she could not stand; I gave her no leave to pawn any thing.

THOMAS FISHER
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce the articles; the prisoner pawned them with me on the 10th of October.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I took the prisoner - she gave up the duplicate.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I expected money to redeem them.
GUILTY . Aged 37.

Confined One Month
.

2078.
BURDETT ROGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, and 1 shilling , the monies of
George Morgan
.

GEORGE MORGAN. I live at a club-house in St. James'-street
- the prisoner was employed there as a painter's labourer . I came home about five o'clock on the 24th of August, and asked him to clean my shoes; I took off my trousers, with this money in them, and put them on a box in the dressing-room - I went down stairs, and in about five minutes I came up again, to take the money out of the trousers; I then missed upwards of 30s.: my fellow-servant came in, and I sent for the prisoner - I asked him if he had picked up this money; he denied it - I told him I would make him pull all his things off; he still denied it, and my fellow-servant went for an officer - while he was gone, the prisoner said if I would not hurt him he would give me the money; he took some of it out; I said that was not all - he then took out the rest from his inside trousers pocket, and laid it down; I went out for a few minutes - when I returned he was gone; he was taken soon after, for something else.

Prisoner's Defence. When the prosecutor came home that day he was quite intoxicated - I was called to go on an errand, and when I returned I went to finish the shoes; I let one of the brushes fall, and in picking it up I saw the money - I should have given it him, but he had some friends at tea.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Confined 1 Month .

2079.
WILLIAM COURTNEY
was indicted for that
he, on the 20th of October , 50lbs. weight of lead, value 6s., the goods of
George William Meriton
, and fixed to a building of his, feloniously did rip, cut, and break, with intent to steal the same; against the Statute .

SAMUEL COCK
. I am an exciseman. The house in question is in Ann-street, Bethnal-green
, and belongs to
George William Meriton
; I collect the rent for him - he lives in the country; I saw the house unroofed last Saturday, but I did not go on the roof - I had seen it safe about a fortnight before.

JOSEPH CASSELL. I am a headborough of Bethnal-green. One Wednesday night I met the watchman, and went with him and the inspector to Ann-street - the door of this house was fastened; it is not inhabited - we got through another house and into that; we looked into a cupboard in a corner, and saw a hole in the cicling; we got into the hole but found nothing - the watchman found the prisoner on the roof.

JOHN PIERCY. I am a watchman. I went to the house, and got through the hole on the roof; I saw the prisoner dragging his legs from the ceiling to get on the roof - I went and took him, and found this knife laying by his side in the gutter - the lead had been cut and turned up for three or four feet; I charged the prisoner with it - he said there was no one there then, but the other had made his escape out of a window - and I heard a window thrown up at the back of the premises; the prisoner said he got up there to lodge - there was nothing on him but a small penknife.

GEORGE CLAY
. I am an inspector of the watch. I went with the witnesses and took the prisoner - it was about half-past twelve o'clock; I found this penknife on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been at work for Abraham Montague till half-past nine o'clock, and then went drinking - and how I got on the house I do not know.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

2080.
ELIZABETH FRAMPTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 20 yards of printed cotton, value 23s. , the goods of
Frederick Head
.

WILLIAM GRAY
. I am an assistant to Mr. Frederick Head, draper , of Oxford-street
. On the 30th of October I saw the prisoner take two pieces of printed cotton from inside the door, put them under her cloak, and walk away; I followed, and brought her back, without losing sight of her; she had dropped the prints as she was going off the door - she went on her knees, and begged I would not send for an officer.
WILLIAM CHURCH. I am an officer, and took her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The witness opened my cloak, and asked what I had got; I said Nothing; he took me back, then brought in the prints, and sent for an officer - I thought it a very hard case when I had not taken it off the door.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Six Weeks .

2081.
BENJAMIN HANTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , two phosphorus-boxes, value 3d.; 1 newspaper, value 2d.; 2 snuff-boxes, value 1s.; 2 jars, value 4d., and 1 book, value 6d. , the goods of
Henry Francis Piaget
.
MR. LEE conducted the prosecution.

HENRY FRANCIS PIAGET
. I keep a circulating library and a tobaconist's shop - the prisoner was my servant . On Friday evening, the 16th of October, I went to my tea-caddy and found the prisoner's hat on it - I took it off and felt it was very heavy; I lifted up his handkerchief, which was in it, and found a phosphorus-box and a newspaper - I sent him up stairs, and called in a person who saw what was in it, and we sent for Mr. Clark; in about half an hour we searched his box, which he opened himself, and found in it one phosphorus-box, two snuff-boxes, two snuff-canisters, and a book, which are mine - these are the articles.

Cross-examined by MR. COLLVER. Q. The prisoner expressed no reluctance to open his box? A. No; he did it by order of Mrs. Clark, his mistress - he is not my apprentice.(Property produced and sworn to.)
JOHN CLARK. I was in the shop while they went up stairs to open the box; the prisoner said he did not know how he came by the things; he knew they were Mr. Piaget's.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you said any thing to him about being prosecuted? A. No; I told him as I had found him out in so many things, I would certainly go to the full extent of the law; he was apprenticed to me, but used to do a few things for the prosecutor, who is single; he has been a good boy till lately, when he has got some bad companions.

EDWARD PAYNE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Whipped and Discharged .

2082.
HENRY LEFEVRE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 1 watch, value 20s., and 1 seal, value 1s. , the goods of
John Hardwick
.

JOHN HARDWICK
. I am a weaver . Last Wednesday I was called to dinner at five minutes before twelve o'clock, and left the watch in the window of the workshop; when I came up in about half an hour it was gone, and the prisoner likewise; he had worked there about six weeks - he gave himself up the next day.
ELIZA MORRIS. I am in the prosecutor's service. My master went down to dinner, and the prisoner sent me out of the shop; I was gone about five minutes, and when I returned he was gone.
WILLIAM CLAMP. I am a pawnbroker. I have a watch pawned with me by the prisoner on Wednesday, between twelve and one o'clock - our house is more than a mile from the prosecutor's.
JAMES HANLEY. The prisoner came and surrendered himself to me last Thursday, and told me where he had pawned the watch.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Two Months .

2083.
JOSEPH KINGSTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 24 pieces of tape, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Jonathan Orme
.

MARY LEE
. I am a shopwoman to Mr. Jonathan Orme, a linen-draper , of Russell-street, Covent-garden
. On the 28th of October the prisoner came in to purchase some webbing for boots - he is a shoemaker; while the personwho was serving him went to get it, he took twenty-four pieces of tape off the counter and put them into his pocket: I told a boy to go and tell Mr. Orme, and just as the prisoner got to the door he stopped him.
Prisoner. It was outside the counter I picked them up. Witness. No; he reached over the counter and took them.

ROBERT ORME. I am the son of Jonathan Orme. Lee sent to me, and as the prisoner was going out I told him he had got a pound of thread, which she said she thought it was; I took him into the passage - he pulled out this tape, begged my pardon, and said he did not mean to keep it; he has come to the shop for three or four years.
Prisoner. I beg for mercy; I have a dying mother and two small sisters at home whom I support.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined One Month .

2084.
JOHN HEWITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 1 saw, value 6s. , the goods of
William Wells
.

WILLIAM WELLS. I lost a saw last Friday from a building at which I was at work in Copenhagen-street
, between twelve o'clock and a quarter before one, while I was gone to dinner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ZECHARIAH PEELE
. I am a carpenter. I was working at the same place; the prosecutor's wife called me to look after a person who was coming out of the building; I went and saw the prisoner coming out and going away - I asked him what he wanted in the building; he said he was looking for a job; I saw he had something under his coat, and drew out this saw.
Cross-examined by MR. COLLYER. Q. Was this in the house? A. No, in the street.

WILLIAM BROWN EDWARDS
. I took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence I was looking for work, and saw this building not finished - there was no carpenter's bench nor tools, but this saw was on the floor; I thought some carpenter had left it by mistake, and I took it to take to the public-house to inquire what carpenter had been at work - the witness came and asked what I meant by stealing the saw: I said I meant to take it to a public-house.
WILLIAM WELLS. I constantly work there - we generally leave our tools on the bench; they were not hid - I was at work up stairs - my bench was on the first floor.
GUILTY . Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined Seven Days .

2085.
MARGARET BYRNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of October , 1 pair of spectacles, value 10s.; 1 ring, value 10s.; 3 keys, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 2d.; 1 pocket, value 1d.; 1 bonnet, value 2d.; 1 knife, value 1d.; 1 snuff-box, value 1d.; 1 pencil-case, value 1d., and 3 thimbles, value 1/2d. , the goods of
James Selling Hewkley
.

JAMES SELLING HEWKLEY
. I missed my wife on the 25th of October - I went to look for her, and found her in Bunhill-row watch-house; the officer had got these articles - I knew them all to be mine, and they had been in my wife's possession.

JOHN BROWN. On Saturday, the 24th of October, the prisoner was brought to Bunhill-row watch-house in a state of intoxication - soon after the prosecutor's wife was brought in, and was placed with the prisoner; she was also intoxicated - the prosecutor came in the course of the night to inquire for his wife; we went into the place, and found his wife laying dead and the prisoner was rising from her person - we took the prisoner, and found all these articles on her, which the prosecutor has identified.

THOMAS WALKER. I was in the watch-house when the deceased was brought in; I saw the prisoner there - these articles were found on her - I believe she did not say any thing; I found this bonnet on her head - I took her to Finsbury watch-house in the morning.

HENRY HARRINGTON
. I received charge of the prisoner. I found this ring on her finger, which she said was her own property, and this duplicate which had belonged to the deceased.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was so intoxicated I did not know what I was doing.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2086.
JOHN SHELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 3 sovereigns, and 19 shillings, the monies of
David Robinson Watts
, his master .

DAVID ROBINSON WATTS
. I keep the Pontefract Castle, in Chapel-street, New-road
. I sent the prisoner with two bottles, containing two gallons of brandy and two gallons of gin: I gave him a bill, and said it was of no consequence about the money, but if he received it he was to bring it me - he went out, but did not return.

ROBERT MURRAY
. I am a shopman to Mr. Laing, of the Haymarket. The prisoner brought the bottles of liquor; Mr. Laing took them, and asked him if he could give him change for a 5l. note - he said No; Mr. Laing then gave him four sovereigns, and he gave him 1s.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I found the prisoner in Fitzroy-market on the 15th of September; he said he had got tipsy and lost the money, which I believe was the case.
NOT GUILTY .

2087. JOSEPH WILKINS
was indicted for
