stealing, on the 28th of October , 1 watch, value 4l.; 1 seal, value 5s.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s., and 1 watch-key, value 1d. the goods of
John Ingram
, from his person .

JOHN INGRAM. I am a camp equipage maker . I was at the Ship public-house at Charing-cross, on the 28th of October; I was not very sober - I left there at five minutes past eight o'clock: when I left, two soldier s came to me and offered to walk with me, and did walk with me to the end of Parliament-street, on my way home to Lambeth - I said I was much abliged to them, and if they chose to take any thing they should have it; we went into the Horse Shoe and Magpie in Bridge-street, and had some rum; I then went on, and soon after I saw the same two soldiers behind me - they came up, looked very hard in my face, and one of them took my watch; it was gone in a moment - I pursued them down the steps into Palaceyard, but I slipped down, sprained my ancle, and could not pursue further; I believe the prisoner is the man who took my watch.
JOHN WHARTON. I am a shopman to Mr. Page, apawnbroker in Vauxhall-bridge-road. The prisoner pawned this watch with me on Friday last; I gave him this duplicate.

JAMES ROGERS
. I am a servant at the Horse Shoe and Magpie. I saw the prosecutor at our house last Wednesday night rather tipsy; the prisoner and another soldier were with him, and they drank together.

FERDINAND JOHNS. I am a constable. On Friday night last I saw the prisoner intoxicated in the street - I took him into custody, and found this duplicate on him; the prosecutor had given notice of this robbery at our watch-house - he said it was a young man in a military undress.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was at a house in Brownlow-street; I left a quarter before nine o'clock, and came straight down to the barracks - I had not been at that part of Westminster the whole day. On Friday a man in a red jacket came to me and said, "Soldier, I will sell you a bargain;" he took me aside, showed me this watch, and said he would sell it for 1l. - I said I had not 1l., but I would give him 15s. for it, as I was no judge of watches; I had never had one in my life - I bought it, and then, as I had to go on furlough, I pawned it to get the money.

ROBERT DUFF. I am pay-serjeant of the company to which the prisoner belongs, in the 3rd regiment of Foot Guards - he was present at the roll call in the King's`mews barracks, at nine o'clock on Wednesday night last; he has been above four years in the regiment, and had a good character for honesty.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Life .

2088.
JAMES WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Joseph Dudley Webb
, from his person .

JOSEPH DUDLEY WEBB
. On Friday last, between four and five o'clock, I was going up Queen's Head-lane, Islington
; three boys followed me, and the eldest, who was this prisoner, pushed against me, and looked me in the face - I put my hand to my pocket, and my handkerchief was gone; the boy had then got on five or six yards before me - I cried Stop thief! ran on, and seized him; I said, "Where is my handkerchief?" he said, "I have not got it, search me;" a youg girl, who stood at a door, said," Your handkerchief is on those steps" - I dragged him back, and took it up; he had passed the others, but they were behind me when I missed my handkerchief; it must have been thrown there before he passed me; I had seen him with two others for a minute or two before.

ELIZABETH HARDING. I live in Queen's Head-lane. I saw this gentleman there; the prisoner picked his pocket, and threw the handkerchief on the steps - I saw it done, and told the gentleman of it; he took up the same handkerchief the prisoner threw down.

JAMES ROOMES
. I am a watchman of Islington. I took the prisoner, and gave him to Mr. Cope the officer.
THOMAS COPE. I received the prisoner, and this handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. There were two boys behind me, and I walked on before the gentleman - he then came, took me, and said, "You have my handkerchief;" I said I had not - the other two boys ran away; the little girl and a gentleman, who was there, said it was not me.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2089.
WILLIAM WILSON
was indicted for
embezlement .

JOHN BARHAM
. I am a baker , and live at the corner of Baker-street, New-road
- the prisoner had been four weeks with me as a weekly servant ; I gave him 12s. a week - he was to take out bread, and to receive money and account for it every afternoon: I was not satisfied with him, and gave him notice to quit - he left me on Saturday, and on Monday I discovered this.

FRANCES DELL
. I deal with the prosecutor - I paid the prisoner on a Thursday or Friday, about the 25th of September, 15s. for his master; it was a weekly bill - he wrote this receipt on it (read); I gave him a half-sovereign, two half-crowns, or 5s.

JOHN BARHAM
. He did not bring me this money; he said they wanted change for a sovereign, and he could not give it.
Prisoner's Defence. I received the money, and paid it to the shopkeeper - the prosecutor was there at the time; he stopped 5s., and said he would make a debt of it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

2090.
WILLIAM MESSENGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 8 feet of deal plank, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Richard Chapman
; and that at the delivery of the King's Gaol of Newgate, holden for the County of Middlesex, at Justice-hall, on Wednesday, the 25th of October, in the 56th year of the reign of George III, he was convicted of felony by the name of William Passenger .

JOHN HARDY
. I am a watchman of Islington. At a quarter-past four o'clock in the morning of the 13th of September, I met the prisoner in the back road with this piece of timber under his arm - I said, "Mate, what is this?" he dropped it, and offered me 1s. 6d. to let him go, but I would not; he was then within a few hundred yards of the prosecutor's.

RICHARD CHAPMAN
, JUN. This was my father's property; his name is Richard. I had seen it safe in the brick field, but I cannot say when; the prisoner had been in our employ three years, but when we found he was a returned transport we discharged him, and since he has been in our employ we have lost twenty-two planks.

Prisoner's Defence. I took this bit of plank by order of the foreman to lay over a dirty ditch, for some of my children to get a penny if they could; the foreman said I might have it if I brought it back at night.

WILLIAM ELLIS
. I produce a copy of the conviction of the prisoner by the name of William Passenger (read).
WILLIAM GALE. I am a timber merchant. I remember the prisoner being tried on that indictment; I attended on the part of my employer - I have no doubt of his being the man.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Transported for Life .

2091.
ALFRED WILKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of October , 2 carpenter's rules, value 3s. , the goods of
James Butler
.

JAMES BUTLER. I am a hardwareman . I lost two rules from my shop window in Tottenham-court-road
, on the 29th of October.

DANIEL FOX. I saw the prisoner take something from the prosecutor's window - he put it into his pocket, and ran away; I told the prosecutor, saw the prisoner taken, and the rules were found on the pavement - the sash was thrown up, he reached over, and took them.
FRANCIS WARWICK. I took the prisoner, and have the rules.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

2092.
LUCY PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of September , 17lbs. weight of leather, value 34s. , the goods of
Thomas Bowtell
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury.

2093.
ANN ROSE WOOD
was indicted for
perjury .

The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury.

2094.
ABEL PIERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of September , 1 silver tea-pot, value 4l. , the goods of
William Cathcart Boyd
.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the property of
Louisa Elizabeth Boyd
.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. On the 25th of September I saw the prisoner and another turn out of Moorfields-square and go, one to South-place and the other to South-street; I went down Cross-street and came up South street - I missed the prisoner, but saw the other man; I went on to Wilson-street, saw the prisoner come up to Wilson-street, and then he ran - I went and took him, and found this tea-pot in his apron.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Did you see the two persons together? A. Yes, walking within a yard of each other; I did not observe any conversation - I think they were not walking in the usual way; the prisoner did not come to me and ask what I wanted - I took hold of his collar; he said he had been to Blackfriars, and found the tea-pot - the other man did not join him afterwards; I took him about thirty yards from the prosecutor's.

CATHERINE JONES. I live servant with Mrs. Louisa Elizabeth Boyd, at No. 2, South-street
. This tea-pot is her's, and was either on the kitchen table, or in the pantry on the 25th of September; the person who took it must have come down the area steps.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you put it at night? A. I used to take it to my bed-room - I am sure I had it in my bed-room the night before, and brought it down that morning; the Lion on the top of it turns round, and I have it in use every day.

ELIZA MILLER
. I am a niece of Mrs. Boyd's; she is married to William Cathcart Boyd.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been over the water to receive orders, and coming down Moorfields I saw a handkerchief on the step of a door - I took it up and put it into my apron - I had not got more than twenty yards, when the officer said, "What have you there?" I went back, and said, "A tea-pot;" and gave it him.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

2095.
CHARLES O'CONNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of November , 1 hat, value 20s. , the goods of
Samuel Adam
.

SAMUEL ADAM
. I am a stone-mason . I was at the Marquis of Granby, Drury-lane
, last Sunday morning, about ten o'clock - my hat was on a cask; I had a pint of beer, and when I looked for my hat it was gone; I had seen the prisoner there - he was gone when I missed my hat; there was another hat left.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS. I went to the prisoner's lodgings in King-street, Drury-lane, about three o'clock on Sunday; he was not there - I went again at two in the morning; he was in bed; he said he had it, but it was a mistake.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it by mistake.
NOT GUILTY .

2096.
ANN COLLINS
,
MARY TEWSBURY
, and
JOHN NEAL
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of October , 1 purse, value 9d.; 3 half-crowns, 4 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the property of
William Rickarby
, from his person .

COLLINS
pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Life .

WILLIAM RICKARBY. I am a linen-draper , and live in Vine-street, Hutton-wall. About eight o'clock last Saturday evening I was going down Holborn, towards home - I had had too much in the course of the afternoon; I met some women, but I have but a very faint recollection of them; I had had a purse with some silver, but I do not know whether I had it at that time.

WILLIAM JEFFREYS. I saw the prosecutor and the three prisoners come into the Castle tavern, Holborn
- they called for half a pint of liquor - the prosecutor took out his purse and paid for it - he had change for half a crown, and put 1s. 6d. into his purse again; his purse had some other silver which looked like half-crowns in it - he put it into his left-hand pocket - I saw Collins put her hand into his pocket and take out his purse; the other two prisoners were sitting opposite her, they saw it, and winked at her - I told the officer, who took Collins, and found the purse on her - they were all taken before they left the box.
-. I am an officer. I took this purse from Collins.(Property produced and sworn to.)

TEWSBURY -
NOT GUILTY .

NEAL -
NOT GUILTY .

2097.
RICHARD MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of October , 1 dead goose, value 4s. , the goods of
Edward Tidyman
.

CHARLES HERBERT
. I am a Police-constable. On the 31st of October, about three minutes after ten o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's - he was running, and carrying a dead goose; I ran after him, and saw he had but one shoe on - I asked what he had got; he said a piece of meat; I asked him to let me look, and saw it was a goose; I asked where hegot it; he said if I would go home with him to the New-road he would tell me; I said it was too far - he then said it was given him; I took him to the watch-house, and found the prosecutor there, who claimed it - the prisoner was very much in liquor.

CHARLES TIDYMAN. I am a poulterer , and live in Hand-court
. I missed a goose from my window - I found it at the watch-house.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it of a woman for 4s. 6d.; I was very tipsy.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Two Months .

2098.
HENRY PEARCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of October , 1 pair of scales, value 5s. , the goods of
John Williams
.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a grocer , and live in Golden-lane
. At ten o'clock on the evening of the 30th of October I was in my back parlour, and saw the prisoner come into my shop - I had seen him before, but not in my shop; he snatched up a pair of scales, and ran off - I followed, and caught him a few yards from the door; he dropped the scales - I know them to be mine: he ran very well, and spoke like a sober man - these are the scales.
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated - I had drank a great deal of liquor; if I had been sober I should not have done it.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

2099.
JAMES WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of November , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
William Sawkins
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2100.
MARGARET BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of November , 1 hat, value 4s., the goods of
John Young
, from his person .

JOHN YOUNG
. I am a mariner . On Sunday morning, about one o'clock, the prisoner took my hat off my head. and ran away with it; I had not walked with her before - wanted me to do so, but I would not; the watchman took me to the watch-house, and showed it to me.

JOHN ANDERSON
. I am a watchman. I met the prisoner about half-past two o'clock in the morning, in Shakespeare-walk
: I asked where she was going - she said home- I asked what she had in her apron: she said Nothing - I found this hat there: she then said she took it out of pawn for 1s. 6d. - this was about two hundred yards from where the prosecutor was robbed.

JURY. Q. Was he in liquor? A. He had had a drop of drink, but was not intoxicated - I found him at three o'clock, and said, "Where is your hat?" he said a woman took it off his head, and ran away with it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the gentleman before- I found the hat in the kennel in Fox's-lane.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Confined Three Months .

2101.
SARAH RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October , 1 scarf, value 5s., the goods of
Ann Freak
, widow , from her person .

ANN FREAK. I am a widow. On the 5th of October I was at the corner of Monmouth-street
, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, and felt my shawl taken off my shoulder - I said, "For God's sake, don't take my shawl;" I saw the prisoner near me: I saw no more of my shawl till I saw it at the Magistrate's the same evening - two officers came up, and assisted me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. Q. Did you ask me to lead you out of the public-house? A. I am not saying contrary to that.

Prisoner. She threw her shawl off when she was sitting on the step of a door, and was sick from the effects of the liquor - she told me to take care of it - I was holding her when the officer came up.

JOHN THURTELL
. I was on my beat that evening, and saw this old lady, who had had a drop, but was not incapable of taking care of herself; the prisoner was with her - she set her down, and then drew the shawl from off her back, and tucked it under her hams; I said to my serjeant,"Do you see that?" he said Yes; I went and asked the prisoner to assist me up with the old lady; she said she was not able; I got her up, and the prisoner took the shawl from her hams, and went away; my serjeant stopped her.

PHILIP RILEY. I am serjeant of the Police. I saw the prisoner shifting the shawl under her - I said to her, "Why don't you assist the woman?" she said, "I am very bad, and can't;" she went away with the shawl, and I stopped her. She and another sat on the step - the old lady sat on the flag-stones; the prisoner had got as far as the public-house when I stopped her.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Three Months .

2102.
JOSEPH GODFREY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of November , 3lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s. 9d. , the goods of
Edward Lees
and
Thomas Russ
.

EDWARD LEES. I am in partnership with Thomas Russ - we are cheesemongers
. Last night, between six and seven o'clock, I had seen the prisoner lurking about, and a friend observed him take this bacon; I followed him, and asked what he was going to do with it - he said it was not mine; I took it from him.

GEORGE CAVE. I was in Mr. Watson's shop, and saw the prisoner in the adjoining passage; I saw him put his arm round into the prosecutor's shop, but I did not see him take the bacon - I saw him for about ten minutes, while I was washing myself: when I got out he was in custody.

WILLIAM PORTEOUS. I was on duty, and a man told me I was wanted - I went, and the prosecutor gave charge of the prisoner, for taking this bacon; he made a violent resistance, and offered 2s. a lb. for the bacon.
EDWARD LEES. This is my bacon - it fell from my hand when I took it from under the prisoner's coat; it could not have been reached without a person stepped into my shop.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take it from the shop, and he did not take it from me - he at first said he found it in the street.
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Confined Three Weeks .

2103.
JOHN HUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 2nd of November , 1 pint of brandy, value 2s. , the goods of the London-dock company
.

WILLIAM OSBORN. I am a London-dock
watchman. I caught the prisoner in the act of broaching a cask of brandy, which laid on the quay, about half-past one o'clock yesterday; I took this bottle of brandy out of his trousers - it has about a pint in it; the prisoner was employed there - there were a good many people about; he had bored a hole, and put a spile in - I asked him to give up his tool, and he gave this gimblet.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q.Was his back to you? A. When he saw me he turned his back to the wall- his back was to me when he was doing something at the cask; the cask was leaking from the hole - the bottle was in his breeches; I cannot say that the contents came from the cask - it appeared to be a brandy cask; I did not taste the contents of it - I did not say yesterday that it was rum - I have not tasted what is in this bottle: it smells like brandy - the cask was in the custody of the dock company.

COURT. Q. Did you taste any of that which came from the hole? A. No - a brandy cask is of a different model to others: it was a sort of cask that brandy is generally brought in - it was on the wharf of the London-dock company, and the prisoner was in their employ.

CHARLES WEBB. I am a cellar-clerk in the spirit-quay of the London-docks. I saw the cask which Osborn pointed out; I dipped it, and found it deficient about one quart - it was brandy, and of the same description as this in the bottle - I tasted them.

Cross-examined. Q. What difference in a cask would one quart make? A. About 2-10ths in the rule; there is not a quart in this bottle, but the cask was leaking - I do not know whether any one else had been there; to the best of my judgment the brandy in the cask and this in the bottle are the same - I have no hesitation at all in swearing that: the prisoner was an extra man there - all persons are searched coming out, and I should think he would have been stopped with it; no sample bottles are allowed there.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not bore the cask - I took the spile out.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, believing it to he his first offence.
Confined Three Months .

2104.
JOHN ROBERTS
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
James Wilbey
, with intent to rob him .

JAMES WILBEY
. The day before yesterday I was going home to Walthamstow, and called on my daughter at Newington. I and my wife had two pints of porter at the Three Crowns - we left at half-past seven o'clock in the evening; I was perfectly sober: when we got to Tile-kiln-lane
, I met three men - I saw them before they came up to us; the prisoner was one of them, and he had a pack at his back - a man on his right-hand struck me, and I fell; in getting up the prisoner's hand was close against my watch; I called out Watch! my wife then said she was struck, and I cried Murder! the men made the best of their way off - I am certain the prisoner was one, and he was in the middle; it was star-light - the prisoner went forty or fifty yards, then came back, and said, "What the devil is the matter?" we called Watch! Watch! he ran, and called Watch! Picket came up, and he had hold of the prisoner; I said that was the very man, and he had been in the centre of the three, with a pack at his back - he is a bird-catcher; neither of the others had a pack - I saw his face quite plain; the officer took charge of him, and he was taken to the watch-house - I did not lose my watch; he put his hand against it, but the seals were in my clothes, and there was nothing for any one to lay hold of.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. He was quite a stranger? A. Yes; there was a lamp in the lane - there were no trees near us; I swear to him both by the fact, and the man himself - I was not muddled; the man who ran away, called Watch! the man who struck against my watch, went away, and came back - he did not say any thing, till he came back; no hand had been thrust into my fob.

MARTHA WILBEY. I am the prosecutor's wife. In Tile Kiln-lane, we met three men; they knocked my husband's hat off - the prisoner put his hand to my husband's watch; he had a pack on his back - I saw it as I picked up my husband's hat; I said, "How dare you insult my husband, he said nothing to you;" one of the others then struck me in the eye.

Cross-examined Q. Had you been with your husband all the afternoon? A. Yes, and drank a little, but not to hurt me - I drank at a grocer's shop, but not at the Three Crowns, only two pints were drank there - I saw a large bunch of onions.

WILLIAM PICKET. I am an officer. I went into Tile Kiln-lane, on my way home; I met three or four men running, who said, "They want you - a man and woman have been insulted down the lane; have you met a man?" I said Yes - they said, "Had he any thing on his back?" I said No - I ran down the hill, and saw the prosecutor; his wife was holding her handkerchief to her eye - I said,"Which way did he go?" they said, "Down the hill;" I ran and overtook the prisoner, who was walking towards the bridge - I said, "You are my prisoner;" he said he was willing to go with me, but he knew nothing of it - the prosecuter said he was the man who tried to take his watch; the prisoner had some onions, and a large package of bird-cages - the prosecutor said he was one of the three that had insulted him, and had put his hand to his watch

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he was the man who clapped his hand to his watch? A.Something like that; the prisoner had a large load - he had some sticks, or poles, and some nets; that is a very common place for bird-catchers on Sundays - there had been several parties of bird-catchers that day.

JAMES WILBEY
re-examined. Q. Were your watch and seals entirely concealed? A. Yes; no one could take hold of it - he put his hand against it; he did not strike me in any other way - I told Henry Watts how we had been used, and he told the officer.

Prisoner's Defence. I got to the high bridge, one hundred or two hundred and fifty yards before the prosecutor - I heard the woman cry out; I turned back and said, "Mistress, what is the matter?" I then went on, but I had lost a little dog, and went back to see for him - I then turned to go home, and met the officer.
NOT GUILTY .
